bibl.title: Letter from John A. Owen, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, December 4, 1947

div1.p: Owen thanks Hench for speaking before the Alpha Omega Alpha society at the University of Virginia. He found Hench's lecture enjoyable and inspiring.

div1.head: Letter from John A. Owen, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, December 4, 1947
div1.opener:
UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA
CHARLOTTESVILLE
ALDERMAN LIBRARY
December 4, 1947.
OFFICE OF THE LIBRARIAN
Dear Dr. Hench,
div1.p:
I am writing just a short letter to tell you how much we
all enjoyed your talk and having you with us at the A.O.A.
banquet last month. We were certainly lucky to get you on such short
notice and your kindness in re-arranging your plans to come here
was greatly appreciated. As for the talk itself, it was thoroughly
enjoyable from every standpoint-- especially, I think, from the
standpoint of impressing us with the adventure of research, and the
high ideals and continual challenge of the medical profession. We
don't get much of that, ordinarily.

As for your suggestions about choice of honorary members of
A.O.A. next Spring, we have all agreed that it is a very good idea.
It is at least an expression of our recognition of the wonderful
achievements of the Walter Reed group of experimenters.

I thought you might be interested in the news photograph of
you taken Monday afternoon; I am enclosing it with this letter.
If you would like me to send you any of the newspaper clippings,
please let me know.

As soon as you have time, please send me an account of any extra
expenses on your part and we shall be most happy to reimburse you.

Thank you again, Dr. Hench, on behalf of us all, for one of
the most fascinating talks we have heard.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, John A. Owen, Jr.
President, Virginia Alpha Chapter,
Alpha Omega Alpha.
